title: Wednesday, 20th April, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Hi there

PM

Welcome

PM

Gonna tray and be really dull today

11:01 am
PM

Dull dull dull

PM

Cos that's what the regulator wants

PM

A dull, grey world

11:01 am
PM

No fun

PM

No conversation

PM

No socialising

11:02 am
PM

dull

PM

dull

PM

dull

11:02 am
PM

PM

Here's what the regulator has found...

PM

Hospitality provided or received did not always appear to be designed to enhance the quality of service to the client. Individuals from firms had participated in or spectated at sporting or social events, eg golf, tennis, concerts. These benefits did not appear capable of enhancing the quality of service to clients as they were either not conducive to business discussions or the discussions could better take place without these activities.

11:02 am
BE

(@squarepeg: it's not.)

PM

here's what the FCA instructs...

PM

When providing or receiving a non-monetary benefit we expect firms to consider and assess whether all aspects of the benefit are designed to enhance the quality of the service to the client including the location and nature of the venue, and those activities which are not conducive or required for business discussions, eg sporting and social events and activities.

11:03 am
PM

What it found....

PM

Hospitality that is not designed to enhance the quality of service to clients is offered in connection with other benefits that do meet the requirements. There were instances of sporting activities like playing golf or attending rugby games provided after participation in training events. Evening dinners, which were not themselves designed to enhance the quality of service to clients, were also provided to local attendees after conferences.

PM

And what it wants...

11:03 am
PM

Where an activity or event provides a number of non-monetary benefits, you must consider each benefit separately. Just because one benefit provided by the firm is designed to enhance the quality of service to a client and is capable of being paid or received without breaching the client’s best interest rule does not mean that another benefit (that does not meet these requirements) can be included in or alongside the compliant activity or event.

BE

Jees.

PM

The FCA, steadily painting the financial world grey

11:04 am
PM

I won't go on.

PM

Dull civil servants, slowly killing the market

PM

Market makers replaced by machines

11:04 am
PM

Analysts being decimated

PM

Fund managers basically ordered to never leave their offices

PM

Misery all round

11:06 am
BE

The current state of regulation reminds me of the Theatres Act 1968.

PM

Me too

PM

Er, what's the Theatres Act 1968?

11:07 am
BE

As in, when the Lord Chamberlain let his reactionary philistinism to govern what was going on.

PM

(CommentGoesHere -- go away)

BE

Leading to all sorts of stupid stuff, like people not being able to carry ladders as suggestive angles.

11:08 am
PM

hahaha

BE

We're currently in the Lord Chamberlain phase of regulation. Overreach of dullness.

BE

I'd hope there will be an equal and opposite pushback, but am not confident.

11:08 am
undefined
BE

To be fair, though, the market itself isn't exactly giving us much thrilling material today.

BE

11:09 am

(Very good The Gifter)

Meaning all we have is ......... Actually, I'm not going to show that FTSE versus Brent graph again.

hahahaha

PM

BE

White's FTSE. Yellow's WTI. Thought I'd do tick chart for two full sessions just to emphasise that, occasionally, it does drift. Though not by much.

11:12 am
BE

So we have oil down a bit today because Kuwait.

BE

http://ftalphavill...l-workers-edition/

BE

And that's all we can say about that really.

11:12 am
undefined
PM

oh dear

PM

omg smile

11:13 am
BE

Yep. So, earnings or miners? Those are our choices.

BE

Seriously, we have months of this. At least. The Brexit malaise is going to be brutal over summer.

BE

Actually, someone on the ROTR mentioned ITV.

11:14 am
ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 230.75, down 7.65 (-3.21%), High: 238.50, Low: 230.30, Volume: 8.85m
PM

Soundbuy

PM

What's behind the drop?

11:15 am
BE

Well, that's a fair question. JPM's got a note out that, on the face of it, is positive.

BE

Though it also flags up the possibility of big acquisitions, which feels less positive.

BE

We've also had rather bleak noises about advertising recently, which are difficult to ignore.

11:16 am
PM

Hmm, that's true

BE

Here's JPM's results preview.

BE

Stock picking remains key within the FTA space. The European FTA space
as a whole has outperformed the wider Media sector by +6% YTD with a
divergent share price performance among the key players (TF1 +14%, ITV
-14%). We expect divergent trends among the space to continue and see
macro (rather than structural themes /TV audience trends in the US) to remain
the key share price driver. Despite the recent underperformance, we remain
positive on ITV and see risk-reward in regards to Brexit as attractive at the
current level with the shares trading on 13.3x/12.3x 2016E/2017 P/E (hist.
average 15.7x) for our +8% 3-yr EPS CAGR. We continue to like TF1 and
M6 as recovery plays in a challenging, but potentially evolving, macro
backdrop in H2 2016.

11:17 am
BE

We keep our view that structural concerns on the European FTA space
are overdone due to: 1) fewer commercial broadcasters in EU countries
compared to the U.S. delivering mass market audiences (just one in the UK,
ITV), 2) much lower CPTs in UK/Europe vs US and 3) a high share of TV
consumption on mobile devices/non-TV sets (we assume up to 30% in key
European markets). With less structural impact, we believe the dominant net
advertising revenue (NAR) driver for European FTA will remain the macro
environment for quite some time.

BE

ITV shares driven by Brexit concerns, but we see risk-reward as
attractive at current levels. We attribute ITV’s recent underperformance
largely to: a) difficult comps in Q116 (Q115 NAR up +12%) and b)
concerns around Brexit. With the shares now trading on 13.3x/12.3x
2016E/2017P/E for our +8% 3-yr EPS CAGR base case (2015-2018E) we
see risk-reward as attractive. The company’s plan potentially to re-leverage
its balance sheet to 1.5x over time (currently 0.6x, on 2016E estimates) may
also add up to 10% upside to EPS.

BE

Seems to me that "Brexit concerns" is a lazy catch-all reason to pin to anything's underperformance. What are we expecting to happen to all these "Brexit concern" stocks if there's a "remain" vote?

11:20 am
BE

Anyway, I'll also flag up Citi yesterday on ITV.

BE

Brexit uncertainty has likely driven ITV’s weak share price performance this year; at 13.6x 2016E P/E it now trades at a -13% discount to its own historical P/E average, and has never been cheaper relative to the market (14% discount). The overhang may remain but our sensitivity analysis implies the market is pricing in a negative advertising scenario already, and ITV could offer a Brexit hedge (Citi economists assume 30-40% probability of an exit vote). We also look at what an acquisition of Entertainment One would do to ITV, update our forecasts (move to 3% NAR 2016E, cutting EPS 4.3%) and target price (280p from 290p) and preview the 1Q trading update. We rate ITV Buy as we think a more cautious scenario is already being reflected in the discounted valuation.

BE

Macro Data Still Supports Positive 2016E NAR

Our analysis suggests that marketers’ view on the financial prospects of their company (IPA Bellwether survey) may be the closest lead indicator for ITV NAR. History tells us that ITV’s rolling average 1-year forward quarterly NAR has only turned negative in the periods that this survey datapoint has been negative. It has not hit negative territory yet and our NAR forecast (+1.7% underlying ex UTV) appears consistent.

The Market May Already be Pricing in Negative NAR

Our sensitivity analysis shows that a 1% move in ITV NAR drives a 2% move in EPS; far less sensitive to NAR moves than going into the last recession as EPS is now more than 3x the level. The market appears to be pricing in a NAR decline of at least -3.5% in 2016E based on ITV’s historical P/E average. If ITV returned to its 3-year average premium vs. the market or traded in line with P7S1 at 17.4x (the most comparable broadcaster given where it is in the cycle and margins), implied NAR would be closer to -7%. A decline similar to the previous recession (-15%) would only take EPS back to 2013 levels.

11:21 am
PM

Actually, on Brexit it is certainly true that a damp cloth has been thrown on pretty much everything. It's everywhere -- you hear it from lawyers, PRs, brokers, ad sales people, everywhere

PM

But yeah, sorry this is a Brexit free zone

BE

ITV results due May 12, incidentally.

11:22 am
BE

Momentum?

PM

oh, right

BE

There are positive signs ...... Positive-ish.

11:24 am
BE

As in, China metal prices edging higher and etc etc.

BE

Investec sees reason to be encouraged, though still isn't going gangbusters.

BE

The rally during Q1 2016 caught many observers off-guard, ourselves
included. Fundamentals in China have mildly improved, but not to the extent
that equity price moves can be fully justified. The rally can largely be
explained by dollar weakness and improved sentiment on the China growth
outlook - hence we expect commodity prices to be primarily driven by these
factors in the near term. We maintain our disincentive price expectations as
markets still need to rebalance, allowing stockpiles to reduce. Equity target
prices have been upgraded and our mining clock moves to 4 o’clock in
recognition that many signalled events have now occurred.

11:25 am
BE

Let me get the Investec Mining Clock.

BE

BE

They should sell those in the gift shop. Investec has a gift shop, right?

11:26 am
BE

 The commodity price rally in Q1 2016 can be largely explained by the weakness
in the US dollar during that period, given the strong inverse correlation that has
emerged between commodity prices and the US dollar in recent months. We do
not see the slight improvement in Chinese economic fundamentals as sufficient
to fully justify a material improvement on our outlook for commodities. We note
this view is shared by many of the major global mining companies.
 Modest upgrades to our near-term commodity forecasts are largely the result of
mark-to-market adjustments following price moves in Q1, rather than changes in
our longer term outlook. We do believe that equity market sentiment towards the
sector has become more positive, resulting in higher valuations, despite ongoing
concerns over earnings and debt. The ongoing equity rally has in many cases
exceeded our value points despite valuation upgrades. We raise price targets on
many companies and recommend a neutral weighting to the sector.
 The fact that Q1 2016 saw many of the milestones we had expected from our
Investec Mining Clock (dividend cuts, asset impairments, credit downgrades and
signs of stability in commodity prices at cyclical lows) means that we now move
forward to 4 o’clock. This signals a mild positive bias toward the sector, although
we caution that the industry still faces some serious challenges: primarily ongoing
balance sheet concerns. Our recommendation is to buy whenever prices
dip below value points. The bottom of the market appears to have been tested
and found, but we do not see this as the beginning of a renewed bull market.
 The sector is effectively healing itself through ongoing asset divestments and
cost and debt reductions. Debt ratios remain a material concern, even if the
market has chosen to reward the most heavily geared companies in the recent
rally. The fact that most such companies did not raise equity during the rally is
indicative of determination not to dilute shareholders unnecessarily when
liquidity is sufficient. Debt buybacks have proved an accretive strategy.
 NPV remains our sole valuation metric but we note that earnings are returning
given the recent increase in commodity prices and ongoing cost cutting.
 We maintain our preference for gold exposure but remain bearish on the
prospects for coal, PGMs, nickel and aluminium.

BE

So on a stocks view, BHP upgraded.

undefined
PM

ARM?

11:29 am
PM

Q1s this morning

PM

This is Markets LIve

BE

Yep, sure. Q1 was quite awful, by Arm's standards.

11:30 am
PM

Awful?

BE

(I refuse to capitalise Arm because you say it "arm", not "Ay Ar Em.")

BE

Yeah, licence sales weak. Revenue misses.

11:31 am
BE

Royalties at the low end of the range.

BE

Costs seem a bit on the high side.

BE

Licence backlog -- the best lead indicator -- down 5% sequentially.

11:32 am
BE

But none of this is a surprise, really.

BE

We know iPhone sales have been a bit poor and that Samsung can't quite find its way.

BE

And you don't buy Arm based on one quarter. Or if you do you've misunderstood why everyone else buys Arm.

11:34 am
BE

See the Jefferies downgrade we wrote up in the paper earlier in the week for the longer debate about long-term risk and reward.

BE

In the meantime, here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

Revenues for Q1 a beat at $398m vs consensus $394m, a much better
print overall than Intel suffering from a tough PC and enterprise server market.
Licensing grew 24% yoy vs consensus 13%. A good result driven by strong
turns business (only 40% of licensing revenues came from backlog), with
strength across the board more around mature products. AROC decreased
from £51m to £35m - so just a timing effect around shipments.
Royalties grew 15% yoy lower than consensus 18% but better than we
feared (13.6% MSe). Weakness in iPhone shipments did not hurt royalties as
much as we feared. Comps were tough with 30% royalty growth in Q1 2015
last year - the two year CAGR is 22%. ASPs were strong at 4.7c up 7% yoy and
in-line with our estimate - also flat qoq. Shipments of 64-bit chips (v8)
continue to penetrate smartphones steadily, reaching 65% of shipments vs
60% last quarter. Octocore penetration reached 25% and Mali 50%.
Guidance for the full year is for 'in-line' with expectations vs 'broadly
in-line' in the previous quarter. Maybe there could be some subtle
rebalancing between royalties (a bit less) and licensing (a bit more) because of
the uncertainty around the Japan production incidents and weakness in PCs
(ARM has exposure to printers, peripherals and printers).
Of note - ARM headcount grew 20% while Intel will cut headcount by 12,000.

11:35 am
PM

Yeah, was going to mention that Intel restructuring -- 12k people

BE

Amazing figure, isn't it? 11% of the workforce.

BE

Credit Suisse too .......

11:36 am
BE

■ Q1 results inline to slightly better. ARM reported Q1 sales of $398.0mn (-
2% qoq/+14% yoy) or £276.4mn (FX rate of 1.44) vs. CS at $395mn
(£273mn, FX of 1.45) and consensus at $394mn (£269mn, FX of 1.46).
Adjusted opex was £132.9mn (+32.9% yoy) vs. CS/consensus at
£129mn/£128mn (£6m headwinds from FX). Adjusted EPS came in at 8.20p
(CS at 8.15p and consensus at 8.06p). Normalised cash generation in Q1
was £80.6mn driving net cash to £1.06bn (or 70.9p per share). Conf call is at
9:30 UK time.
■ Stronger licensing partly offset by slightly weaker royalties. Licensing
revenues were $135.3mn (-3% qoq/+24% yoy) vs. CS/consensus at
$122mn/$123mn with backlog down -5% qoq (it was -7%+2%-7%+10% qoq
in Q1/Q2/Q3/Q415). ARM signed 39 processor licenses during Q1 incl. 8
Cortex-A (including 2 for future generations of advanced processors) and 2
Mali graphics. PD Royalties were $191.9mn (-2% qoq/+15% yoy) vs.
CS/consensus at $200mn/$198mn vs. industry revenues being down -3%
yoy. ARM saw shipments of 280mn 64-bit chips (100mn of which also using
big.LITTLE) from its customers (6.8% of all chips shipped in Q1 using 64-bit
vs. 3.5%/4.4%/6.0%/6.0% in Q1/Q2/Q3/Q415).
■ Guidance – In-line with consensus as expected. For 2016, ARM expects
group USD revenues to be in-line with market expectations (CS/consensus
at $1.65bn, +11% yoy). ARM also expects licensing pipeline for the rest of
2016 to be robust driven by next-gen products, which along with continued
v8/64-bit adoption will drive future revenues.
■ What does it mean for numbers? Extrapolating results (largely in-line on all
metrics), we believe that consensus numbers are likely to remain unchanged
with 2016/2017/2018 sales growing 11% CAGR with EPS of 34p/39p/46p.

BE

Just looking at Intel .... Trading at 13 times 2017 or thereabouts.

BE

While Arm's trading in the mid 50s on 2017, I think.

11:39 am
PM

hmm -- didnt realise Arm was that expensive

BE

Would have to check but it tends to be about that level.

BE

Now clearly, the shift from PC to handheld has destroyed Intel's core market.

11:40 am
BE

But spin forward five years and both Arm and Intel are competing for servers, networking, discrete embedded, etc etc etc.

BE

Now, I'm a huge fanboi of Arm (at a corporate, rather than a stock level). But it seems to me people are pricing in Arm's success and Intel's failure in the new markets, which isn't a bet I'd be wanting to take.

Chemical giant ChemChina [CNNCC.UL] approached BG Group with a possible bid late last year, just as Royal Dutch Shell (RDSa.L) was preparing to close a $52 billion deal to buy the British energy company, seven banking and industry sources with knowledge of the matter said.

PM

hmm

AM

But a very interesting portrait nonetheless.

11:55 am

PM

Thanks for that Arash

PM

We'll let you get on

Thanks for un-dulling us

undefined
BE

Which is my cue to re-dull us. Though with what?

11:56 am
BE

N Brown, maybe?

PM

oh please

N Brown Group PLC (BWNG:LSE): Last: 270.40, down 45.2 (-14.32%), High: 287.90, Low: 264.70, Volume: 5.55m
11:56 am
BE

So here's what happened.

BE

Next warned on its catalogue business.

BE

Said that demand was weaker and FCA rules on credit meant it was getting more difficult to roll over its most lucrative customers.

11:58 am
BE

Everyone said, "um ... N Brown is like a standalone Next Directory so ....."

BE

And today, N Brown says demand was weaker and FCA rules on credit meant it was getting more difficult to roll over its most lucrative customers.

BE

And everyone acts shocked.

11:58 am
BE

Markets are baffling sometimes.

BE

Let me get some figures for the depth of downgrades.

PM

The FCA really is out to sink the wider UK economy as well now?

11:59 am
BE

Ah, well. I'm not entirely against the FCA putting tougher rules on frock shops rolling over their cash cows.

BE

(That's a troubling phrase with reference to N Brown, I belatedly realise, so I'd appreciate if you all ignore it.)

BE

Regulatory over-reach sometimes reaches the right bits anyway.

12:01 pm
BE

Here's Jefferies.

BE

FY16 was as expected, though we cut our FY17 PBT £6m to £86m to absorb FX
headwinds and planned clearance of legacy aged inventory. But we view EPS
to be trending along the trough, the dividend as robust (4.5% yield), and see
BWNG positioning for a stronger future. Buy.
FY16 results in line. £84.5m PBT (before IAS39 restatement) achieved our £83.9m forecast
& the £84.3m company compiled consensus.The 23.9% tax rate vs prior guidance at c20%
is the only real variance to our model (though a 20% rate is steered for FY17F). £290m net
debt (JEFe £288m) & 14.23p DPS (JEFe 14.23p) both as expected.
Ongoing progress in areas of strategic focus. Both Jacamo (on a strong comp)
& Simply Be grew 2H sales c10%, JD Williams sales (now reported without Ambrose
Wilson) rose 4.7% over the year, internet sales grew 15% (penetration 65% vs 59% FY15),
active customer accounts grew 2.2% yoy (+6.9% among the Power Brands), Famous Five
homewear categories grew 12%, the US moved into 2H profit ($0.2m) & Financial Services
returned to growth 2H (new credit recruits increased 136k in FY16). Fit 4 the Future is on
time & budget.
Traditional brands now also in focus. FY16 sales here (22% of the product mix) fell
5.5% yoy. This fed a small loss of share within the older age group womenswear markets
& a small 0.4% drop in BWNG's "most loyal" customers. "Decisive" action is planned: new
focus on marketing, promotions & product. The group looks to the Autumn season for
improvement.
Guidance: Group sales are down since year-end. The sector is currently challenging but
marketing has been moderated from large TV campaigns a year ago to a more phased
approach this year (including more digital spend) targeting higher ROI over the full season.
But there is an FX headwind (c£3m) & the decision to clear legacy aged inventory to absorb,
reflected in group FY17 product gross margin guidance of down 50bp to 150bp. Other
steers: Financial Services gross margin -50bp to +50bp, op costs up 2%-4% before D&A
at £29-30m, net interest at £8-9m, capex at £38-40m & £2m exceptional for ongoing tax
disputes. Reflecting this, we cut FY16F/17F PBT to £86.2m/£96.5 (from £92.6m/£101.6m).
Valuation/Risks
We see underpinning by both a solid DPS (4.5% FY17F yield / 1.7x covered by EPS) & strong
balance sheet (£290m net debt overshadowed by the £527m debtor book). Our 415p price
target reflects 15x FY18F EPS. Risks include; UK retail trends, bad debt/debtor book, sector
valuation, FX, strategy & F4tF execution risks.

BE

And Stifel.

12:02 pm
BE

Full year results are in line, but trading weakened significantly in the tail end of the year and has remained weak, with sales declines to date in the new financial year. While management is confident that some of the trading weakness can normalise, it is clear that market conditions are tough. This is further reflected in guidance of a significant product gross margin decline for FY17, impacted by FX and the need to invest in price to gain share. Systems investments are on track but will see big changes this year and management warns of potential “bumps in the road”. While the shares are not expensive and could well fall in line with earnings downgrades today, we think they fairly reflect the balance of risks and hence we retain a Hold recommendation.

BE

Management states that sales have been lower year on year since the
(February) year-end, citing a challenging industry backdrop since January and
a changed marketing approach. Marketing spend is being phased more evenly
across the quarter rather than in big TV campaigns and hence management
expects the performance to improve over the course of the quarter.
Perhaps more importantly though, gross margin guidance for FY17 is very
cautious, with management guiding to product gross margin down 50bps to
150bps (FX headwind £3m at current rates, stock clearance and tactical
pricing activity to seek share gains in a “challenging market”). Financial
services gross margin guidance -50bps to +50bps. Other guidances are in line
with expectations, including cost growth of 2% to 4% and capex dropping back
to £38m-£40m.
Using the mid range of these guidances we believe consensus FY17 PBT
estimates may fall at least 5%, or potentially more dependent on sales
estimates.
